thread.title: Lamberti: Passaic Valley thinks pink on the soccer field
thread.title_full: Lamberti: Passaic Valley thinks pink on the soccer field

title: Lamberti: Passaic Valley thinks pink on the soccer field
text:
Buy this photo photo courtesy of kathleen berthold AWARENESS - Passaic Valley girls' soccer player Kayla Campbell, right, will honor her mother Vicki Campbell, along with her teammates and coach at Friday afternoon's home match against Fair Lawn for being a breast cancer survivor in recognition of Breast Cancer Awareness month. 
Kathleen Berthold has found her first year as head coach of the Passaic Valley girls' soccer team an eventful one. 
A young Hornets squad has battled a tough schedule, but the team continues to show signs of improvement. Unfortunately, two of the team's better players, Ashley Pabon, a senior, and junior Melisa Conguta, were lost for the rest of the season because of injury. Buy this photo photo by jim alcorn CLOSE CALL - Piero Batarseh, left, and the top-seed Passaic Valley boys' soccer team were eliminated from the Passaic County Tournament with a loss to rivals Wayne Valley this past weekend. 
"That was a game changer for us," said Berthold, noting that both girls were hurt on the same play, in a game against Pompton Lakes. 
There are some interesting events coming up for the team, starting this Friday, Oct. 16, when the Hornets host Fair Lawn. 
"With October as Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we had shirts made for the entire program that read "Some Of The Strongest Women are Soccer Moms. We Wear Pink for One of Our Own." 
According to Berthold, Vicki Campbell, the mother of Passaic Valley soccer player Kayla Campbell, is a breast cancer survivor and will be cancer-free for one year, as of Nov. 12. 
"Vicki is the only mom in our program to go through this journey, so we highlighted her (last) name on the back of the shirts," said Berthold. "In addition to announcing and presenting flowers to Mrs. Campbell, we are going to verbally recognize any aunt or grandmother that is a part of the team that has also battled, or lost the battle as a remembrance. 
"We will be presenting flowers to them, if they can attend the game, or otherwise, we'll present them to the player, in honor of the women." 
Berthold also announced a few more plans for Friday. 
"We are going to decorate the field with pink balloons and all the usual fun stuff," the coach said. "I'm going to attempt to organize the girls in the shape of the (Breast Cancer Awareness) ribbon, on the field, and get an aerial picture." 
If you know Kathleen Berthold, both as a Passaic Valley athlete from the late 1990's and now, as an educator and coach at her alma mater, this endeavor on Friday should come as no surprise. Kathleen is the epitome of Passaic Valley pride, with a big heart and wonderful Green and White spirit. 
After Friday's game, the team will stay home on Oct. 20 to face Wayne Valley, starting at 4 p.m. 
The PV boys' soccer team was eliminated from the Passaic County Tournament last Saturday, losing in overtime to Wayne Valley, 2-1, in Little Falls in the quarterfinal round. 
The Hornets were the top seed in the PCT, but fell short in a tough game. Zachary Fitzgerald scored the lone PV goal, off an assist by Phil Schirner. 
The Hornets took a 7-4 record into a game with Wayne Hills earlier this week. On Oct. 16, it's off to Fair Lawn for a 4 p.m. game. On Oct. 20, the Hornets will visit Wayne Valley, also at 4 p.m. 
The Homecoming festivities at Passaic Valley last Saturday were well done. Kudos to athletic director, Patty Lynch, for putting together the event. The weather was perfect, the crowd was very enthusiastic and the kids were tremendous. 
Sorry to hear the normally fired up public address announcers, Rob Carcich and John Mazzo, a little laid back in their play-by-play of last Saturday's very exciting football game with West Milford. Missed hearing the out-of-town scores, too. Mazzo and Carcich have done, and continue to do, a great job bringing in some fun to the games, regardless of the score. Anyway, felt that should be mentioned. 
Also, give football head coach Chet Parlavecchio credit. As ticked off as he was with the officiating in the second half of the game (which was bad, to say the least), the coach gave a passionate speech to his players, postgame, commending their effort to compete. 
"Football is supposed to be fun," Chet said to his players. "Did you have fun today? That was a good football game." 
Chet gets it. Good for him.
